title: AB 2656
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 48412 of the Education Code is amended to allow persons 16 years or older, or in 10th grade for one academic year, to verify basic skills proficiency for a "certificate of proficiency" equivalent to a high school diploma. The department will maintain a record of all certificates issued. The department will develop competency standards in basic skills taught in public high schools and conduct regular examinations in the fall and spring semesters to verify competency. Exams will be scheduled to allow for timely notification of results before the end of the semester in most school districts. The department may conduct examinations during summer recess or at other times as needed for eligible persons with religious convictions or physical handicaps. The department may charge a fee for examination applications to cover costs, not exceeding the cost of test renewal. Fees collected will be used for department expenses, with excess funds going to the General Fund. Examinees meeting specific criteria are exempt from the fee. Examinees meeting specific criteria, such as being homeless or a foster youth under 25 years old, are exempt from examination fees. Verification of homeless status can be done by a homeless services provider. The state board will adopt rules and regulations for implementing the section, including emergency regulations if necessary. The department will review the effectiveness of examinations periodically, with costs recovered through fees. The Superintendent must report to the Legislature by December 1, 2018, on homeless and foster youth taking high school proficiency tests, the impact of waived fees, future test takers, funding recommendations, administrative costs, and contractor reimbursements. The annual reimbursement to contractors for foster youth services is outlined, with a deadline for reporting set for January 1, 2020. Additional state funds cannot be allocated for this purpose. Foster youth are defined as individuals removed from their homes by the juvenile court under specific sections of the Welfare and Institutions Code. Section 51421.5 of the Education Code is amended to waive fees for homeless or foster youth under 25 years old taking exams. The Education Code waives exam fees for homeless or foster youth under 25 years old. Homeless youth can verify their status through a homeless services provider. No additional state funds will be allocated for this purpose. The Superintendent may use surplus funds to reimburse contractors for lost fees related to waiving exam fees for homeless or foster youth. A report must be submitted to the Legislature by December 1, 2018, detailing this provision. The Superintendent may adopt emergency regulations to implement provisions related to homeless and foster youth taking high school equivalency tests at no cost. This includes data on test takers, future projections, funding recommendations, administrative costs, and contractor reimbursements. The department will include a provision in memorandums of understanding with contractors for high school equivalency tests, stating that ongoing fee waiver costs for eligible examinees will be covered by the contractor if surplus funds are depleted. A "foster youth" is defined as a child removed from their home by the juvenile court under specific sections of the Welfare and Institutions Code. Section 51421.5 of the Education Code, added in 2015, is amended to waive fees for homeless or foster youth under 25 taking exams. This provision will be inoperative by July 1, 2019, and repealed by January 1, 2020, unless extended by a later statute. The Education Code waives exam fees for homeless or foster youth under 25. Homeless services providers can verify housing status for eligible examinees. No additional state funds will be allocated for this purpose. The Superintendent will adopt emergency regulations for implementing the waiver of exam fees for homeless or foster youth. The department will include a provision in contracts for high school equivalency tests to cover ongoing costs if surplus funds are depleted. "Foster youth" is defined as individuals meeting specific criteria. Children removed from their homes by the juvenile court under specific sections of the Welfare and Institutions Code will be covered by this section starting July 1, 2019.
